Since you're a researcher, Kristen, you should get a mutt from the pound, and
study its behavior to discover its traits.  Isn't that more fun than getting a
dog from which you'll discover nothing new because you already know all of its
characteristics?  Just my 2 cents.

On Thu, 24 Feb 2005 14:23 , Kristen Gurba <kgurba@mindspring.com> sent:

>--- Tom Martin tmartin@ncifcrf.gov> wrote:
>
>> Ha!  I have a 1999 black Toyota Corolla with 47k. 
>> Living one mile from work for several years really
>> helped.
>
>Yeah, well.. well.. you just don't get to enjoy the amazing Toyota driving
experience as much!  So THERE.  And ha-ha, white cars show dirt better than
black.  Take that.
>
>Yeah the 80 mile day commute isn't helping ... I *did* live 5 miles from work
for a whole year and a half, but then I had to go and get another job.  Oh well.
 That's why I got a Corrola, they get great gas mileage and I know I can out 200k
+ miles on it without any problem.  I really wanted a Prius, but with the long
commute, I am not sure how economic it would be, since I'm doing 70-75mph the
whole time, and I think the electric engine kicks over to gas over 50mph..
(correct me if I'm wrong?)
>
> 
>> You should get a mutt!  They're healthier--the whole
>> hybrid vigor thing. 
>
>and Michaele countered:
>
>> There are pros and cons to both.  Mutts are not
>> necessarily healthier.  It depends on the dog and
>> where you get them.  
>
>Ah-ha!  And the debate begins.. see, I hear this every day - "Get a mutt", "NO!
Get a pure bred!"  
>My first inclination would be towards getting a mutt at the pound, as I like the
idea of saving a dog.  But, I do like the idea of having a breeder because then
you know what traits the dog will have, and it won't be such a surprise.  Plus
you know their health history, etc.  I've been afraid to go to a pound so far,
because I know I'll go home with a dog without being really prepared.  
>
>As with everything, more research is needed..
>
